Users can instantly classify waste into trash, recycling, and compost. We experimented with several convolutional neural network architectures to detect and classify waste items. Our best model, a deep learning residual neural network with 50 layers, achieved an average precision of 0.881 on the test set. We demonstrated the performance and efficiency of our app on a set of real-world images.

Introduction

Every year, the world generates over 2 billion tons of solid waste. In the U.S., despite 75% of this waste being capable of being recycled, only 34% is actually recycled. Furthermore, 91% of plastic isn't recycled, and only about 5% of food and other organic waste is composted. This waste generates over 1.5 billion metric tons of CO2-equivalent greenhouse gases, contributing nearly as much to climate change as all the cars on U.S. roads. Despite massive investment to educate the public about accurate waste disposal, efforts so far have been only moderately successful. People are often confused by what they can recycle or compost. Signs and boards near waste bins are difficult to understand and are often incomplete. Disposal of waste varies based on local recycling facilities' capabilities, and therefore rules for disposal are subject to change on a county-by-county basis. Errors in waste disposal constitute not only missed opportunities to recycle or compost but also lead to the contamination of recycling and compost bins. Data from the National Waste and Recycling Association shows that human confusion in the identification and correct disposal of waste into our waste bins results in nearly 25% of recyclables getting contaminated, diverting materials that could be recycled into landfills. When a recyclable or compostable material ends up in a landfill, it releases methane, which is several times more potent than CO2 in contributing to global warming.

Clearly, current ways to inform the public have not been working very well. In this work, we leverage the recent improvements of convolutional neural networks (CNNs) for image-recognition tasks and the availability of increased computational power on modern-day cell phones to provide a novel approach for waste identification that is fast, low-cost, and accurate for anyone, anywhere. We present DeepWaste, the first mobile app targeted at the problem of erroneous waste disposal, at the point of disposal, through deep learning. We constructed a fully-annotated dataset of over 1200 waste items that was trained to achieve our best-performing model with an average precision of 0.881 on the test set.

Tackling Climate Change with Machine Learning workshop at NeurIPS 2020.

Previous Work

The topic of waste classification has begun garnering some interest in research, but the attempts reported across literature to solve this problem have suffered from low accuracy (ranging from 22% to 70%) or a network size that is too big for real-time application. Further, most of the previous attempts to mitigate the aforementioned problem of erroneous disposal envisioned deployment within a "smart bin" or the use of a commercial and industrial-grade binning system within a recycling plant, requiring expensive hardware that costs thousands of dollars. The high cost of these solutions has so far been a deterrent to their large-scale adoption. Our approach is novel, as it allows the use of widely available mobile phones, and therefore has the potential for large-scale adoption at little or no cost. Finally, none of the previous approaches have targeted compost classification. This is a significant problem because when compostable material such as food scraps and green waste gets into a landfill, it is generally compacted down and covered. This removes the oxygen and causes it to break down in an anaerobic process. Eventually, this releases methane, a greenhouse gas that is 25 times more potent than carbon dioxide in warming the earth over a 100-year timescale (and more than 80 times on a 20-year timescale).

Our work is the first work in literature, to the best of our knowledge, that considers not only recycling but also compost as a new category for classification.

Methods

Classifying waste using machine learning is challenging for three reasons. First, whether a waste is recyclable or compostable or not depends on the properties of the material, which can be hard to detect simply from the image. Second, the material can come in any shape, such as a broken bottle, or a crumpled can, or deformed plastic; any machine learning technique needs to deal with this variation. Third, material that is recyclable depends on various factors, including the type of material, its condition, and the local recycling facilities' capabilities.
